reviewText:
My feelings on this game are mixed, since I never played the original I have little to no point of reference to compare the two. It's hard when playing against the AI, I'd go so far as to say it's a puzzle game. You basically replay a map over and over in the campaign until you've mapped out the AI's moves because you are usually under gunned and pressed for time which the AI digs in and runs down the clock.

It's difficult to get the drop on the AI because it seems to anticipate your every move. Difficult - frustrating. There's a decent selection of game modes for skirmish and the multiplayer scene isn't as dead as smaller niche games out there so you'll probably find someone to play with depending on the time of day.

I'm still a bit confused as to why you can't change the name of the protagonist which appears hard coded to appear as 'Tactics' for some confusing reason. The UI is clunky and controller support will leave you at a disadvantage over people who play with a mouse. There are a couple bugs yet to be worked out and the game crashed once during my play test, since the game auto saves after every turn it was no big deal.

This is a turn based game where you can easily invest ten plus minutes in each turn but if that's your forte it's worth your time.

reviewText:
Want a graphical stylish tactical squad turnbased game? Continue reading!..

Gamemodes included with the game is: A singleplayer campaign, Multiplayer and Skirmish.

So what about the story? Well you are a hired elite soldier for the rebels. your goal is to overthrow a powerfull coperation.The story progress through a city map screen where you can click to progress or hear what characters have to say through potraits with a text window.

You controll a team of elite soldiers and you need to outsmart the Ai on the battlefield. You must plan carefully every move for your soldiers. If it goes wrong? Restart and change tactics. The Ai will and can change tactics on the battlefield. (Note! I recommend playing through the 2 tutorials so you get a hang of the game and mechanics before starting a game.)

Gfx, interface and levels ingame is clean and stylish. Levels are clever and tactical and fun to play, They will surely give you a challenge but they can be beaten. Iam counting myself as newbie tactical but i havent found a level yet that have been unbeatable. My only complain is the campaign wich is a big city map wich you click to progress your game. Nothing wrong with the map but you can only read what characters want to say but not really talk to them. Also you can not setup your team weapons and outfitt, those are premade for each missions instead.

The sound effects are good and music does what it should. Some speech for the text screens would have been nice.

When you have beaten campaign you can play skirmish. I think the game will be enjoyable for a longtime in skirmish because you can change almost every aspect of the rules, soldiers weapons  and generated maps or why not use the pre-generated maps with other settings.

The game also includes multiplayer. And i can imagine myself the game can be alot of fun with friends for a laugh or two. Sadly i wont include a multiplayer review due to litle time online.

GFx 8,5/10
SFx 7,0/10 (Music included)
Interface and game mechanics 9/10 (Slick, stylish and clean. Great controlls)
Story 5,0-10 (Story feels like last thought, its not bad but feels a bit cheap with no animated story that is progressing through campaign.)

So do i recommend this game? YES!.. Price is a bit high so buy it on sale. Its a game every tactical gamer should have in library.

End notes!
I have read that some reviewers complaining about Ai and windows? Just have a guard and have him sweep it and he will kill what comes in front of it. And if you want to move in front of window just click knee and then dash to not to be seen. It was fully explained in the tutorial howto do it. I have done it in my missions and it worked alltimes. Sometimes i did misstakes and the Ai got the upper hand but just restart untill you know what you did wrong in frist place. Or better press space so the timeframe can show what will happen if you end turn. It will only show seconds but it will give a glimps view what can happen. Use it often and wisely. ;)

As allways english is not my main language. But i have tried my best to get it readable. Cheers

All in all, an amazing revitalization of an already amazing game.

If you have the original Frozen Synapse, don't get this game unless you're willing to drop $25 on a nice graphics. I got this in a bundle, so I pretty much bypassed the  $25 price tag.

On to the game itself, it plays just like the original game. You issue orders to your dudes, such as run here, look in the direction as you walk, crouch, etc. Then you press play and watch your plan act out as your opponent(AI or player) acts out their pre-made plan at the same time. Team with the last man standing wins.

Unlike most people, I like the new graphics, and also unlike them I liked the keyboard controls, and actually prefer it over the original game. The controller support is perfect, with all the right mapping to make the experience smooth. There's more feedback on what the various map, game mode, and team setup do, and easier to mess around with. There's plenty of interesting pre-made maps and scenarios to screw with, plus the map generator and campaign.

So the game is definitely fun, with nice controls and graphics, BUT it's a reskin of the original but with more polish. I would not get this if you don't think what I mentioned above is worth it. Even if you do want this, I suggest waiting for a price drop/sale.

tl;dr -> Tried a tactical rush into superior flanking positions but forgot to order my men to check every corner and got owned real bad. 11/10 good reminder that you are not a tactical genius.

A very generous friend gifted this game to me, and I was interested to try it out because I enjoy tactical turn-based games. I was satisfied with my gameplay experience.

If you like tactical turn-based games, strategy, and futuristic, sci-fi themes, then you will enjoy this game.

The aesthetics are decent - the character models and amount of detail in the levels are average, however, the assets (character models, level design) are extremely repetitive and can get stale quickly. The music and sounds are good and add a relaxing feel to the game, although I muted the music in favor of my own after half an hour. The story is good, but nothing special - you act as a member of a rebel organization trying to break the hierarchy of power and oppression in a futuristic world. There is a lot of optional lore you can go through in the form of character dialogues.

The controls are slightly complex and can take a bit of getting used to if you are not experienced with tactical turn-based games. There is a set of tutorial missions that will help you get a feel for the gameplay. The learning curve is minimal to moderate depending on your experience with this genre. Characters die with one hit, so micromanaging every single step and action is critical to success (ex: check every corner and angle as you move).

Gameplay consists of you planning out moves for each of your units each turn, then executing it once you are ready (this counts as one round). You can experiment with potential enemy movements to help you better plan out your strategies, which is something I thought was interesting. There is no fog of war, so you can always see the entire map, including enemy locations without having to first spot them. reviewText:
Frozen Synapse Prime isn’t so much a sequel to the original as it is a reboot. A new look with updated, swanky graphics, some more options for combat, giving you greater control over the outcomes; and a revamped multiplayer system. All together, there’s not that much new going on. The new commands now allow your units to ignore or focus on a particular room, and also allows them to focus on one particular point while moving, not exactly ground-breaking beyond the initial mechanics. While the graphics quite nice to look at, they’ve been implemented at a sacrifice to UI cleanness and clarity; and graphical smoothness. All the units move a little sluggishly, making the game feel less fast-paced, less tense.

The UI is nothing short of clunky. You can’t give a unit a move order while in the every-other-order dial, which requires a button to bring up and close. Space bar opens the turn predictor and closes while pause, fast forward and back have different keys again. The UI is clearly designed for the PS Vita touchscreen which doesn’t translate well to the PC.

Frozen Synapse Prime’s single player is pretty poor. The strength in the series is ultimately in its multiplayer. While adding an extra game mode and revamping the old ones, FSP wholly fails because of its multiplayer. Not that it’s doing anything too wrong, but more because there are just not enough players. FSP hasn’t got a large enough player-base to keep new players in the game. I played several matches against some European players (European a guess from their names), but most matches were never continued once the other player decided they were going to lose, a bit of a killjoy. I booted the game yesterday and there was only one player online… me, and zero matches waiting to be started.

I’m hoping I’m just a victim of the right game, wrong console. I imagine the game would actually be a lot smoother on the PS3 and PS Vita with more players online. Otherwise, despite the graphical upgrade, Frozen Synapse Prime isn’t really worth it, unless you can grab a group of friends to play with.

reviewText:
Do you love it when a plan comes together? If so Frozen Synapse Prime is the game you want to try.

Image a world where you command mindless soldiers that do -Exactly- what you tell them to do.
Walk forward to a doorway, quickly sweep in front of it, now check behind you to make sure no one is there, quickly step out the door, duck behind this cover and keep moving.

Forget to check somewhere or plan for something, a detail left unaccounted for, that troop might die. A lot of Frozen Synapse is just spent in between turns going over and over that single turns plan, trying to account for every possible scenario and picking the best one. It sounds tedious and maybe it is to some extent but when you get a full map all quickly and efficiently doing what you told them to do and it works even better than you planned, its an amazing feeling. That feeling of knowing you used your brain and got the best possible outcome because of it is what makes this game good.

Frozen Synapse Prime is a remake, sure, but its done well. Graphics are actually good now compared to the original, SFX, game balancing and a few other changes to make the story a shorter and more enjoyable experience. The first one had gameplay at its heart but several things kept me from really enjoying it. This version, Prime, takes care of those and is the gem that the developers truly intended.

reviewText:
Do I recommend this game? Yes.

Do I recommend it at 23.99€ (or your regional equivalent)? No. Get it on sale if you can.

[So what is Frozen Synapse Prime?]

Essentially it's a turn-based game where each player takes their turn simulataneously. The pieces (soldiers) are set, their movfed choreographed and the round is then played out. The aim is to kill the other team before they kill you. It's very tactical and a lot of fun as you squirm in your seat, hoping the enemy team didn't place a sniper around the next corner.

With friends it's a really great time.

Get it if you're looking for something like this, but as I said, make sure it's on sale.

reviewText:
I was iffy about Frozen Synapse Prime with all the bad reviews, but I got it as part of a bundle so no big deal at least to me. The game itself is actually really good. It's a great take on RTS and it makes me think. Overall I've enjoyed the single player mode, but have yet to get very far in the campaign, or participate in multiplayer yet.

The reason for many of the bad reviews that I see is because the difference between Frozen Synapse and Frozen Synapse Prime isn't really much. No new content, no dramatic changes, just a few tweaks here and there and that's it. So if you played the original and bought Prime expecting another great experience, nope. You're getting Frozen Synapse again.

Overall if you haven't played Frozen Synapse then get whichever of the two is cheapest, if you have Frozen Synapse already, save your money.
